stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you describe the cardiac action potential?

prompts.text: Describe the phases of the ventricular myocyte action potential.
expectedKeyFacts: Phase 0: Rapid depolarisation — voltage-gated sodium channels open
Phase 1: Early repolarisation — sodium channels close, potassium efflux begins
Phase 2: Plateau — calcium influx balances potassium efflux
Phase 3: Repolarisation — calcium channels close, potassium efflux continues
Phase 4: Resting potential — maintained by Na+/K+-ATPase
Resting potential ~-90 mV, peak +20 mV
Duration ~250-300 ms

prompts.text: What is the significance of the plateau phase in cardiac muscle?
expectedKeyFacts: Prolonged depolarisation due to L-type calcium channels
Calcium influx triggers calcium-induced calcium release from sarcoplasmic reticulum
Enables sustained contraction — unlike skeletal muscle
Long refractory period prevents tetanic contraction
Ensures adequate ventricular filling between beats
Vulnerable period during phase 3 — risk of arrhythmias if stimulated

prompts.text: How does the pacemaker cell action potential differ from ventricular myocytes?
expectedKeyFacts: No true resting potential — spontaneous depolarisation (phase 4)
Pacemaker potential: slow depolarisation due to 'funny current' (If) — sodium influx
Also calcium leak channels contribute
Maximum diastolic potential ~-60 mV (less negative than ventricle)
Phase 0: calcium influx (not sodium) — slower upstroke
No plateau phase
Autonomic modulation: sympathetic increases If, parasympathetic (vagal) increases potassium efflux

prompts.text: How do class III antiarrhythmic drugs work and what are the risks?
expectedKeyFacts: Block potassium channels — prolong phase 3 repolarisation
Increase action potential duration and refractory period
Examples: amiodarone, sotalol
Prevent re-entry arrhythmias by prolonging refractoriness
Risk: excessive QT prolongation
Torsades de pointes — polymorphic VT
Triggered activity during early after-depolarisations
Worse with hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia, bradycardia

prompts.text: Why does the heart have a long refractory period compared to skeletal muscle?
expectedKeyFacts: Absolute refractory period ~250 ms — coincides with mechanical systole
Prevents tetanic contraction which would be fatal
Ensures adequate diastolic filling time
Allows coordinated sequential contraction
Skeletal muscle short refractory period allows tetanus for sustained force
Heart requires rhythmic relaxation for circulatory function
Relative refractory period allows premature beats but with reduced force

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the role of calcium in the cardiac action potential — when does it enter the cell and what does it do?
keyFacts: Phase 2: plateau (Ca²+ influx balances K+ efflux)
Pacemaker cells: spontaneous depolarisation, funny current (If)
Class III drugs block K+ channels — prolong AP
Torsades de pointes risk with QT prolongation

scoringGuidance.pass: Correctly describes 5 phases with ion movements, explains plateau phase and calcium's role, distinguishes pacemaker from ventricular AP, understands refractory period significance, knows class III drug mechanism; stronger candidates explain funny current and triggered activity
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows phases exist but unclear on ion movements, mentions calcium but vague on significance, confused about pacemaker vs ventricular cells
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe phases, does not understand ion channels or currents, unaware of plateau significance or refractory period, no knowledge of pacemaker physiology
